channel.title: Funny things on Aliens in the Apple
channel.description: Recent content in Funny things on Aliens in the Apple

item.title: Making Marica Grate Again!
item.description: As the cruel parents we are, tonight we decided to make Marica grate – again: Sorry, couldn’t resist. But after I thought of the pun, I think there’s a serious point here, along the lines of that P.

item.title: Holy bubbles
item.description: I’ve been searching for a preschool for Laurelin for a couple of mornings a week. I think it’ll be good for her, and it will help the two older girls and me get a bit more done in school.

item.title: The twelve days of Homeschooling
item.description: A homeschool friend shared this video with me recently, and I got such a kick out of it, I just have to share it here too! Enjoy.

item.title: April Fool’s Dinner
item.description: A few years back, on a whim, I decided to start a fun tradition for April Fool’s Day dinner: dessert for dinner (and no need to have dinner for dessert!). Turns out the kids think this is great, but the adults give a little groan at the thought.

item.title: You can’t see me!
item.description: At lunch the other day, Laurelin was playing peek-a-boo with her bib, which was hilariously cute, because she’d stare out the neck hole at us thinking she was invisible!

item.title: If your daughter asks you for french toast…
item.description: If your daughter asks you for French toast, then you’ll be tempted to just say ‘no’. It’s a weekday, after all. But then you’ll remember that you want to be more of a ‘yes’ parent than a ‘no’ parent.

item.title: Enthralled by the TV
item.description: My computer desk is just next to the couch, and one day while I was doing things on the computer and the girls were watching a show, I looked over and just had to quickly snap a picture of the girls enjoying it!

item.title: Miss Communication
item.description: I was folding washing this morning listening to Marica and Esther talk, and just had to share this funny: E: “Mawica, dose are nithe octoputheth.” M: “They aren’t octopuses, they’re decorations! E: “Dey look like octoputheth…”

item.title: A bonus Laurelin feature
item.description: This post is specially for grandparents, aunties and other such doting people who would be interested in these videos of our little Lorax. Marica loves to play rough and tumble with Laurelin, but she’s very careful not to be too rough.

item.title: Reaga
item.description: Reaga is a mix between reading and yoga. Marica has invented it without even knowing! The other day I was sitting at the computer doing stuff when I saw something out of the corner of my eye that didn’t look quite right.

item.title: Elisabeth Elliot, you’re being milked!
item.description: Reference: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Passion_and_Purity :-)

item.title: Woody’s disgrace
item.description: The other day I found this: It just tickled my funny bone that Esther would dress Woody in a dress! Despite the brave face he’s putting on, he’s secretly mortified.

item.title: Getting out of a tight spot
item.description: The other day Ben and I were walking along when we spotted a car that had been very tightly parked in. The back: The front: Lo and behold, imagine our disbelief and glee when we see the person whose car it is come along and get in the car and proceed to get out of the spot!

item.title: Life in limbo
item.description: Since the last time I posted, we’ve moved into our temporary apartment for the month of March, settled into a daily routine with homeschooling in the mornings, and all of us have gotten sick. New climate, new bugs — it was to be expected!

item.title: A little riddle for you
item.description: Last night I was sitting down and my mind thought up a riddle all by itself. It’s useful like that. See if you can figure it out: What can see light but has never seen the sun;

item.title: The empty pair of trousers
item.description: Esther walked past my study this morning and said, “Dad, I see you in your office, but there’s nothing inside your pants!” Almost certainly thinking of this Dr Seuss book, here’s what she had seen:

item.title: Roadtrip: Lone Pine
item.description: The next stop couldn’t have been more different from Las Vegas. Tranquil, rural, isolated, pretty much nobody around, right in nature, and no electricity! We stayed the night in a little cabin/tent outside a small town called Lone Pine, between the Death Valley and the Sierra Nevada Mountains.

item.title: Helping to push
item.description: We were having a picnic in Prospect Park when Lizel was here and there was this man doing his stretches against a tree. We joked with the kids that the man was trying to push over the tree, and do they want to go and help him?

item.title: Some people just can’t eat cake like normal people
item.description: Some of you might remember Jeremy and Lillian’s bizarre cake eating rituals at their wedding ceremony in New Zealand. Well, it would seem the strangeness just keeps on going. Just look at the mess they made of my beautiful lemon cake.

item.title: If llamas could get braces…
item.description: …then this guy would set off a metal detector a mile away.

item.title: Because your dog is worth it
Adventures with hippos
item.description: In Central Park there is this cool playground that has a herd of hippos made out of fibre glass (?? I guess). The kids always think it’s fun to pretend to ride the hippos. So do some of the adults.

item.title: Blessed hands, broken grammar
item.description: Saw this the other day near where we live and couldn’t help but chuckle a little. You need to read the sign in the window too.

item.title: Quantum Enlightenment Dynamics
item.description: The other day we received an incredible free magazine: NEWLIFE EXPO — America’s Largest Mind, Body, Spirit Expo. Its highly intelligent content, its carefully-placed typos, and its cohesive aesthetic have provided Franci and me with more belly laughs than any comedy magazine ever could.

item.title: Because we’re so normal
item.description: We sometimes have dinner wearing cabbage leaf hats. (Well, only if I’m making coleslaw to go with our pulled pork and need to get rid of some cabbage leaves!)

item.title: Pics from Jeremy’s bachelor party
item.description: Last Saturday afternoon and evening, a few of Jeremy’s Philadelphia friends organized a bachelor party for him. They captured him, got in a little bit of trouble with the Philly police, and drove him blind-folded all the way to New York, where I joined them for dinner.

item.title: Tips for new New Yorkers
item.description: It takes a lot of adjusting to live in the greatest city in the world, and there are some protocols that you should follow if you want to survive in this city. You might be a kind, generous and gentle person in the privacy of your own home, but follow these tips for how to act in public, and within a couple of weeks you will not only feel like a real New Yorker, but look like it to anyone watching.

item.title: If looks could kill…
item.description: then this cheeky face kills me with laughter almost every time I see it. Figuratively, of course. She was putting on her pretend grouchy face, only to dissolve into giggles herself!

item.title: A hairy theme at the Met
item.description: Every time I go to the Metropolitan Museum of Art I see something I haven’t seen before, and I certainly go back to old favourites. Recently I took some photos with a hairy theme. Some of them are so ridiculous, you’d have to be an old stodge not to even get a slight smile at the lips.

item.title: Where there’s a will, there’s a way
item.description: As shown by this very stubborn plant determined to grow on a church steeple in Baltimore.

item.title: Don’t mess with this guy
item.description: I took his photo one day while walking the Brooklyn Bridge. I wonder if he’s ticked off at the cyclists that come hooning down at breakneck speeds, or if he’s just having a bad day?

item.title: The Person’s Prayer
item.description: Our Caregiver in the spiritual realm, Transparent be your name. Your democracy be voted in, Your social policy be implemented, In reality as it is in the spiritual realm. Give us every day our organic tofu,

item.title: Travelling fruit
item.description: This little guy has come a long way! And he tasted pretty good too. A taste of home, you could say. :-)

item.title: Your office is where?!
item.description: I often see this sign on the wall of a house on my walk to the hospital (and I’ve done that walk a few times recently) and it cracks me up every single time.

item.title: Taking kids on a photo shoot can be interesting
item.description: And also pretty fun. Perhaps “photo shoot” is too formal a title for what we did with Jeremy and Lillian, but I still tried to get a heap of photos while at the same time trying to keep an eye on two speedy escape artists.

item.title: Luth3r hacks iChurch, makes Bible open source
item.description: GENEVA TRIBUNE, August 1517. New things are afoot in the world of Scripture freedom. Two days ago a hacker, who goes under the pseudonym Mart1n Luth3r, released a set of 95 bullet points outlining how to hack iChurch’s core systems.

item.title: Turning 30
item.description: Last Thursday I (Ben) turned 30, and an otherwise ordinary workday was turned into Something Special by my lovely wife. She’d been being secretive about something for a few weeks, so I guessed something was going to happen, but I had no idea what.

item.title: How Jeremy eats a mushroom
item.description: When we were visiting Jeremy in Philly, I made some grilled mushrooms on the barbecue with fresh parmesan, salt, pepper, butter and fresh mozzarella cheese, garnished with a fresh basil leaf. Are your mouths watering yet?

item.title: Visit to Mr. J
item.description: A couple of weekends ago, we visited our good friend, Jeremy, in Philadelphia. What a blast — we did some sight-seeing, but also my favourite pastime: having good discussions over good food. There was of course also an appropriate amount of teasing which Jeremy thrived upon.

item.title: White Collar in Clinton Hill!
item.description: Yesterday and today we’ve had film crews on our street and surrounding neighborhood shooting for the TV series WhiteCollar. It’s been really cool to see a little glimpse of what goes into a production like this — SO many trucks and people doing all sorts of things.

item.title: Proof that we are Americanizing
item.description: I have Uncrustables in my freezer. Yes, ma’am, I tell no lie. Uncrustables in your freezer means that you have attained to the great feat of crossing over to The Other Side. For any of you ignorant folk who do not know about the beauty of Uncrustables, let me introduce you.

item.title: Cheeky grin
item.description: This girly has some awesome facial expressions. This is one of them. :-)

item.title: Up to no good
item.description: Esther’s fine motor skills are very well developed, at least when it comes to opening things. Somehow she managed to open the coffee packet the other day and spill grounds all over the floor. But then you see that expression and how can’t you laugh?

item.title: Where to find me
item.description: … in a subway station. Or my initials, at least. :-) The real place you’ll find me in a subway station is as far away from the tracks as possible, holding onto my kids pretty well!

item.title: Beauty is in the eye of the beholder
item.description: Marica said I looked beautiful after she was finished making me beautiful. Ben came home and called me hideous. I’ll let you decide for yourself! It was cold and rainy a fair bit back in March, so one day when Marica asked if she could make me pretty, I consented.

item.title: The importance of a decimal point
item.description: You might not think it, but it can make quite a big difference!

item.title: Don’t be late for class!
item.description: Or else… We saw this on the subway to church the other day and I couldn’t help it — I just had to take a picture! Sometimes graffiti is hilarious.

item.title: Would you?
item.description: Would you feel confident using a dry cleaner with a name like this? It cracks me up every time I see it! I took the photo at night, so excuse the poor lighting.

item.title: An uncultured laugh (specially for April Fool’s day)
item.description: When I went to The Cloisters with Hannah and Eva, there were a few sculptures/carvings that I took pictures of purely to post on here with funny comments, because they sure made us crack up. My apologies go to the artists who did not create their masterpieces for us to laugh at, and to those of you who find Roman Catholic artefacts more meaningful than un-cultured moi.

item.title: Marica’s self-photography
item.description: Just a little something that I hope you find as funny as I did! A post explaining the make-up on the eyes is coming soon…

item.title: Is it vague, or is it lazy?
item.description: This article is best read out loud for maximum effect. I like read this interesting article the other day, and, you know, I thought it was pretty interesting, so I thought I’d like link to it.

item.title: A joyful glimpse
item.description: I just wanted to share a little moment in our life here, because it’s moments like these that make me so happy and thankful for the gift of being able to be a mother at home with my kids.

item.title: Who left the toilet open this time?
item.description: I recently discovered Esther in the act of playing with her favourite toy again. She was in her element, and had even put a washcloth and some bath toys in there too. She even washed herself with the washcloth, as you can see.

item.title: Getting creative with snow
item.description: We’ve had a lot of snow here this winter, and today we’ve got snow and ice rain again! Well, life carries on about as normally as it can and we try to get out when we can.

item.title: Snowsational
item.description: Snow is beautiful. And fun. It does get messy, and it keeps you indoors more than you’d like, but those are trifles compared to the six foot high piles of white-or-grey frozen stuff all over the streets.

item.title: Sally Henny Penny
item.description: Those of you familiar with Beatrix Potter’s stories would appreciate this picture of our very own Sally Henny Penny wearing her yellow stockings. Very soon she will be going barefoot barefoot barefoot! And no, we hadn’t brushed her hair yet!

item.title: Having a bad day parenting? Sue McDonald’s!
item.description: Warning: This article may contain traces of sarcasm. Maybe she was just having a bad day as a parent. Or who knows, maybe she is getting paid by an advocacy group. But one Mizz Parham from California seems to have a thing against Happy Meals.

item.title: Our first snowman
item.description: It got seriously warm today (almost 10 degrees C), so we went into our snow-covered backyard and colonized it, turning the beautiful fresh snow into a snowman. Our back “yard” before we started: Laying the foundation (Marica supervising):

item.title: Through Marica’s eyes
item.description: Marica absolutely loves being allowed to use the camera to take photos. And I always have a chuckle when I download them and see just what caught her eye. Let’s just say that she has a realistic view and she takes pictures of it — she won’t avoid the messy room.

item.title: Well there you go!
item.description: We saw this billboard with graffiti on on our way home from the Bronx Zoo and I just had to take a picture. What a great commentary on how our society thinks — “it’s all about you”, never mind others, just go ahead and bless yourself!

item.title: If you’re ever feeling a bit glum…
item.description: and need a reason to put a smile on your face, then here are 2: Now, let’s go pull radish together! Just watch out for thorny hedgehog! I love Chinglish! (Special thanks to my friend Anna for taking these pictures for me!

item.title: Esther’s new favourite toy
item.description: Esther loves water. She has also recently started pulling herself up on things. I guess it is to be expected that she would have found the toilet very entertaining! Esther and the toilet seem to have a magnetic attraction to each other.

item.title: Rubber ducky
item.description: Something we saw plastered on a wall near Little Italy. If your sense of humour is anything like mine, you’ll find this pretty funny.

item.title: Lady Liberty
item.description: The other night I was busy in the kitchen setting the table and suddenly wondered why Marica was so quiet. I looked up and saw this. Totally unprompted, and she got the pose and everything right!

item.title: Oops
item.description: Couldn’t help smiling yet at the same time feeling sorry for whoever this belongs to:

item.title: Marica’s sayings on Twitter
item.description: I don’t understand the appeal of Twitter. Just as you’re three quarters of the way through your controversial opening statement, you have t… But anyway, Franci and I did find a good use for it. You know all those weird and wonderful things three-year-olds say but you always forget to write down?

item.title: Little bits of update
item.description: I’m slowly settling into the groove of life here in NYC again and today we ventured out to the Prospect Park Zoo. I’m sure you with dial-up will be delighted to know that I forgot my camera at home.

item.title: All Natural!
item.description: Ben and I have had lots of chuckles over some product labelling here in the U.S. lately. The term “all natural” seems to be plastered on everything. With such a label, you would assume “healthy”, but is anything edible not natural (in the sense that it has been derived from nature?

item.title: Quirky New York
item.description: So far we’ve noticed a few quirky things here in New York. For instance, the light switches are the other way around than in NZ - up is on and down is off. I still get confused.
